item.description:
The RFID bill is coming up for a public hearing on Monday, March 9th. HB0478 Relative to remotely readable devices and relative to the illegal use of a payment card scanning device or reencoder.

The current bill is open to public hearing on Monday, March 9, 2009 at 1:30 PM in LOB 302. Please check here for the latest time/date of the hearing.

This bill requires notification of embedded RFID tags and suchlike in non-obvious products e.g. clothing. Updates language relating to illegal activities with payment cards to recognize newer technologies than mag-stripe. Prohibits many government abuses of tracking technologies. One or two other provisions.

You can read the text of the bill at http://www.gencourt.s...

"Besides the other good stuff in the bill like RFID labeling, this bill would explicitly prohibit the state from putting RFID in driver's licenses and other documents."

Additional Notes:
Bottom line, although this bill mandates certain new behaviors on retailers and their supply chains, they are not especially onerous, and certainly will not form any restraint upon trade, and meanwhile the bill benefits the privacy of the individual and places highly desirable limitations upon the state.

This bill has a score of a 22.5 Pro-Liberty bill by the NHLA.
item.name: HB0478: RFID / Pseudo-Real ID
